author: .vbuterin
content:
One nuance here is that the role of "home staker" is getting disaggregated somewhat. Basically, you have two choices:

1. Be a home attester + focil operator. Then your hardware reqs will not go up much (likely, they will go up in 2026 and then back down in 2027), but you would have to outsource block building
2. Be a home block builder. Then you will need heavy hardware. Realistically, this should be done by businesses and community groups, not individuals.

author: .vbuterin
content: I agree we need more venues for this. I know <@552133098075193354> was thinking about splitting up ACD more, and adding a separate call to talk about long-term vision questions

author: .vbuterin
content: Though I think calls are a bit overrated

author: ben_a_adams
content:
Why do you need code introspection?

> To read handcrafted proxies written using legacy bytecode https://x.com/optimizoor/status/1917205654521188520

Covered with option D; can do that from EOF

author: ben_a_adams
content:
What remains a  problematic dev use case in option D? Can it be quantified or specified?

What is the technical blocker? Nothing can be learned if we don't establish what this is.

author: gakonst
content:
IMO we have credible path towards low resource + low stake req FOCIL, and that's where we'll get our CR. 

The block builder world optimizes for getting users the good parts of MEV and is also downstream of private orderflow market dynamics, no world we get back to local block building dominating, that ship sailed years ago.

author: gakonst
content:
RE: Alexey's point on the strategy for the runtime...here's my strawman roadmap.

The first and least disruptive goal imo is improving performance by recalibrating the gas schedule (Ben A & others have been doing awesome work on the opcode repricing wg). Main things for me are: 
1. make existing compute really cheap + introduce new compute opcodes for really common math in DeFi (sqrt, log2, count leading zeros etc)
2. Making new storage allocation much more expensive (like 10-25x potentially) to protect against excessive state growth, make same block warm storage access and writes similar to TLOAD/TSTORE, given every client has read and write-through periodically flushed mem caches. 

The bottleneck in our numbers is not the interpreter, it's generally host-related things (precompiles, db) so things that improve the VM itself perf wise are nice but not high ROI.

The second one IMO is further improvements to the developer experience, where there's a clutch change on memory pricing which addresses both Solidity being unable to implement spilling cheaply, and Vyper's ability to do dynamic types.

Beyond that I think there is probably another surgical change in the AA neighborhood which would allow users to submit txs that don't pay ETH in the txpool, but are only valid if paired with an ETH paying tx, kinda like a native bundle type. (I understand the AA team's concerns on censorship etc I think we don't need to worry about these in the txpool as they'll be addressed by FOCIL)

I don't think EVMMAX/EVM SIMD make sense or are good ideas as the cryptography toolkit you need to do serious ZKPs is mostly there already, and again isn't the bottleneck in systems I see given they all end up verifying an EC SNARK which is well supported. I could see the case eg for a poseidon precompile, but that's a smol thing.

author: gakonst
content: Going beyond that, I think seriously exploring how to grow the smart contract dev base is important. So R5 I find exciting bc I can get Rust and C devs to write Ethereum code, and I'd love to find a way to also get Python or JS devs sandboxes that work within Ethereum smart contracts. I think it's doable.

author: gakonst
content:
On security, I agree it'd be great if we were more structured there which is where part of my EOF excitement originated, ultimately I think EVM security is top notch in present moment vs every other crypto eco, so while I'd love to invest more in it, it's lower on my priority list given a mature set of tools, auditor professionals, best practices, open source culture and a trained dev base. So to me it's just lower in the priority list, esp given most noobie devs write pretty well tested contracts these days with coverage, fuzzing and soon a linter etc we give via Foundry.

RE the FV argument, I would love it to be true, my understanding is that people gotta learn to write good properties, and that's what gets you results in fuzzing / FV. So I'm not sure the VM would 10x things there if devs don't learn how to write good properties

author: gakonst
content: (Wrote this in one go on mobile so apologies for typos or phrasing)

author: ben_a_adams
content: So no remaining technical blocker on EOF; you just veto'd against consensus because you think its not a great ROI; even though (using sunk cost fallacy to cancel prior work); there was little remaining investment, so it would be all return

author: gakonst
content:
Sorry I was responding to the VM strategy point, and basically EOF was bottom of that list. I evaluated it w/o sunk cost or R5 as an alternative. 

Many devex points were not thought out and the EOF dev process felt like patchwork vs a well thought out ecosystem upgrade, which ultimately made me lose trust on it being sound and new things surfacing in the 11th hour which would compromise peerdas time-line

author: gakonst
content: You don't need to rehaul the VM to make killer surgical improvements!

author: gakonst
content: In hindsight my biggest mistake which I regret is not realizing all this stuff 1yr ago, and it was my failure not doing enough diligence vs listening / trusting others

Just not tools and libraries which is fine,  EOF is optional.

author: sky.cactus
content: IIRC, the reason it appears "patchwork" is because people keep wanting changes of all sorts and the team building EOF has bent over backwards to accommodate everyone in hopes it would eventually get approved.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: And while turning the gas limit up to 11 is a small code change (arguably 0 lines), it is a massive overhaul in terms of what is required to actually achieve it in reality.

author: g11tech

author: g11tech

author: sky.cactus
content: Giving veto power to small groups encourages ossification, which is what I have wanted for a long time.  However, most core devs are strongly opposed to ossification.

author: g11tech
content: its not a veto power bestowed to anyone, if someone/group makes valid and convincing arguments, it makes sense to re-evaluate

author: sky.cactus
content: Most likely what will occur as fallout from this is taking away that veto power through process changes, to ensure that Ethereum never ossified.  One day you'll see a change go through that you think is a very bad idea and suddenly dislike the "fixed" process.

author: g11tech
content: going forward I am assuming that SFI is going to be stricter in terms of readniess as well as the value prop

author: sky.cactus
content: From the tone of the conversation above, it seems like most people believed that EOF was quite ready and had a good value prop.  It was still canceled none the less, because there were a small number of people who disagreed.  This is the veto power I refer to and I don't think making SFI stricter will remove that.

author: gakonst

author: gakonst
content: You're just not engaging with the app dev audience and that app devs don't live in this channel...

author: gakonst
content: 0 changes is how Ethereum becomes irrelevant. Sorry this is plain wrong.

author: gakonst
content: Totally, that's right. Large change should have a holistic strategy. The fact that even few weeks ago we had TXCREATE come up, for a super 101 Ethereum use case is telling that we didn't have a holistic understanding of how app devs use contracts, which is a huge failure. All this stuff should've been years ago. EOF could have graduated university, people complete PhDs in 5 years, if we couldn't lock it in a while ago, it's telling.

author: gakonst
content:
BTW I want to be explicit: I am using up my own credibility in this conversation, at no personal gain, because I want Ethereum to win. I don't want to be neither an asshole, nor a weird dev that subverted process according to some.

But there's tons of people in my DMs supporting me being "the bad guy" to this group, as a voice of reason to them, who are afraid to speak up because there's a culture of social acceptance and conflict avoidance, and that's the largest problem in Ethereum Core Dev. 

Please talk to users, and if you disagree with things please speak up, letting things "run" is worse than speaking up early. Relationships become stronger through respectful conflict resolution and tackling it head on.

author: gakonst
content: (I respect Ben and co pushing against my takes in a super respectful & nuanced way and think that's great)

author: gakonst

author: ben_a_adams
content:
Both had tons of changes ðŸ™‚

IPv6 is literally version 6; TCP has gone through lots of changes and ultimately is getting dropped for QUIC because its too ossified (so HTTP/3 doen't use TCP anymore)

author: ben_a_adams
content: SMTP is a better example (email); but everyone hates the protocol

author: axic3354
content: SMTP has too many "app level" workarounds and scaffoldings to fix many of its shortcomings that it became a living nightmare

author: sky.cactus
content: IPv4 to IPv6 is an opt-in migration.  Same with TCP to QUIC.  I am a huge fan of moving tech forward and building new things.  I am only against pushing those changes onto people.  I would wholeheartedly support Ethereum 2.0 and likely become more involved in the development process if that happened.  I would also stop pulling my money out of Ethereum 1.0 and looking for alternative places to put it like I am now.  The reason I support ossification is not because I dislike tech or change, it is because I am strongly against using network effects to push changes onto people without their explicit opt-in.

author: ben_a_adams
content: Yeah, but it hasn't really changed ðŸ˜‰

author: axic3354
content: It didnt, they made the "app" layer to "fix" it ðŸ™‚

author: ben_a_adams
content: EOF is also opt-in; no one is forced to use it, and would unlikely ever try and migrate wETH, USDT, USDC etc to EOF; so legacy is here to stay and EOF is a dev choice

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, I was arguing against <@486477492434239488>'s claim that Ethereum will become irrelevant (on timescales that people care about) if it doesn't constantly push changes onto users.  I wasn't arguing about EOF vs not EOF.

author: ben_a_adams
content: I do lean with <@486477492434239488> on most of the performance changes (while maintaining decentralization, and other properties of Ethereum etc)

author: gakonst
content:
If Ethereum was the only game in town, maybe I'd be open to ossification. Right now there's a race to who becomes TCP, and there's path dependence, which requires exteme thoughtfulness on every step along the way to get to that. 

Otherwise another L1 will become TCP, and we're gonna be a bunch of strangers on the internet arguing in this channel while we lost.

author: gakonst
content: I wish we were in 2015, I really do, but it's hard to state how rough of a position Ethereum is in if we don't accelerate development and prioritization aggressively to not get eaten by competition. I don't need to debate you on it, it's a fact you can choose to disagree with.

author: gakonst
content: Yep hence large thoughtfulness needed on new storage pricing, and network implications around the MEV auction mostly to lower slot times.

content: repricing will need every test redone; so is a small/BIG change ðŸ™‚

author: sendmoodz
content: just want to add as an application developer i very much agree with <@486477492434239488> take. i dont think this is one client doing a veto. there are a lot of people who think the roi of eof is simply not worth it. would add that shipping the change to the evm is not the end of the work. there is tons of work downstream of the change, including for application developers, and i dont see any benefits to me (the situation with fv and static analysis will not change--i use halmos for small functions but writing invariant tests for complex contracts is very difficult or impossible). even if i decide not to use it, i have to fully understand it because almost all useful contracts call into other untrusted contracts

author: robocopsgonemad
content:
ok look, before everyone gets all "Justin doesn't care about appdevs!" i'd like to direct everyone to the existing network upgrade process 

https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7723  (if there is another ACD policy documented somewhere else, please cite it and I would love to take it into consideration.)

and illustrate to me, how appdev opposition to an SFI'd EIP is to be handled.

Then we can get on to the matter of squaring that with what actually happened. I started my convesation in this channel on the matter asking for *reconciliation*, and that specific topic has been avoided and skirted. Numerous other people have also brought the matter up, and it has been ignored.

author: sky.cactus
content:
I believe it goes something like:
App devs convince one or more client dev teams that the EIP is bad.  Client dev teams then exercise this clause:
> An EIP **MAY** be moved from `Scheduled for Inclusion` to `Declined for Inclusion` if client teams are against including the EIP in the network upgrade.

author: robocopsgonemad
content: I think a reading of "MAY" and "teams" in a manner that squares this is an incredible stretch considering all context.

author: sky.cactus
content: The plurality of teams is certainly up for debate.  I think MAY is fine here, it has a precise technical definition in this context.

author: ben_a_adams
content: and "against" ðŸ˜‰

author: alexsharp12
content: <@486477492434239488> replying to your "roadmap" that you showed above. It is not a strategy yet, because it identifies what you'd like to happen, but not how. When I studied Solana, I noticed that it too performed multiple repricing of the operations, but for Solana it was much easier than for EVM, guess why? Because the gas (it is called "compute units" but is essentially gas) is unobservable for the smart contracts from the beginning. Gas un-observability makes repricing almost trivial. For your excitement to Risk-V, as I already pointed out, but it is again does not seem to be understood. EOF is "Object Format". So the main feature is not changes in EVM, but in organising the code structure. Which can also be very helpful when doing RISCV. And essential when you want to make backwards compatible transition. When I looked at EOF in a lot of details couple of months ago (thanks to <@425274498732916736> for taking time to explain), it did not see anything there which could be explained by "drive to perfectionism".  Things are as simple as possible, but not simpler. It went even further, by offering a whole "menu" of options with different set of features. When EOF was acceped on ACD a month or so ago, I thought it would not, because the strategy containing it was obviously absent. So it was not surprising for me to see it being excluded, because without strategy, it did not have a chance IMO. I am not trying to get it re-included, I just wish for the implications for what is being done to be understood.

author: robocopsgonemad
content: and the singular form of EIP, since these were all DFI'd in total, which I think really captures the disconnect we have here on agreement for Option D

author: frangio_
content:
eof is opt-in on the surface but there's nuance to it and second order effects. if it's not sufficiently compatible with and close to legacy, it creates maintenace burden for libraries and tools, and eventually a split where some only support one. at that point dev choice becomes dev burden in dealing with a split ecosystem. this kind of split can be a huge source of frustration (see js cjs vs esm, python2 v python3) that risks losing more dev mindshare

unfortunately, for complex reasons, contract libraries use a lot of inline assembly, and so the incompatibilities can't just be fixed at the compiler level

this is why i favored option D + create&create2, at least in the contract library space i dont see how that would cause a split

author: _shemnon
content: What you describe is option C, where the whole code observability epic would be removed too.

author: glasscipher
content: A split would potentially come down the line, when "EOFv2 with introspection banning" gets brought up.

author: lu_pinto
content: Sorry for stating the obvious but can't have both worlds. Either with or without introspection. We will have the same convo with RISCv down the line if it happens

author: lu_pinto
content: Solana doesn't seem to have gas or code introspection from what I skimmed. Could have missed something

author: alexsharp12
content: Solana does not have code/gas introspection. It also has an object format, and therefore can perform memory-mapping from storage to memory, and thus use regular programming structures, like `struct` and `enum`, instead of scattering everything with Keccak around a hash-table. I believe gas introspection would not be available in a RISC-V system, unless one decides to specifically botch it for this reason. I believe if someone does not know how to live without gas or code introspection, they will be able to learn in a few months. The vast majority of software in the world does not require these features, and it still works ðŸ™‚
